Benchmark.title: FDCC: Guidance for Securing Microsoft Windows Vista Firewall for IT Professional
Benchmark.description: This guide has been created to assist IT professionals, in effectively securing systems with Microsoft Vista Firewall
Benchmark.notice: Do not attempt to implement any of the settings in this guide without first testing them in a non-operational environment. NIST assumes no responsibility whatsoever for its use by other parties, and makes no guarantees, expressed or implied, about its quality, reliability, or any other characteristic. NIST would appreciate acknowledgement if the document and template are used.
Benchmark.rear-matter:
Trademark Information
Microsoft, Windows, Windows XP, Windows Vista, Internet Explorer, and Windows Firewall are either registered trademarks or trademarks of Microsoft Corporation in the United States and other countries.
All other names are registered trademarks or trademarks of their respective companies.

reference.dc:publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology

Profile.title: 800-53 Low
Profile.description: This profile selects specific controls that are recommended by Special Publication 800-53 for information systems in which all three security objectives (i.e., confidentiality, integrity, and availability) are assigned a FIPS 199 potential impact value of low. Each control has an effect on other groups within this document as individual rule require certain controls to be selected.

Profile.title: 800-53 Moderate
Profile.description: This profile selects specific controls that are recommended by Special Publication 800-53 for information systems in which at least one security objectives (i.e., confidentiality, integrity, and availability) are assigned a FIPS 199 potential impact value of moderate and no security objective is assigned a FIPS 199 potential impact value of high. Each control has an effect on other groups within this document as individual rule require certain controls to be selected.

Profile.title: 800-53 High
Profile.description: This profile selects specific controls that are recommended by Special Publication 800-53 for information systems in which at least one security objectives (i.e., confidentiality, integrity, and availability) are assigned a FIPS 199 potential impact value of high. Each control has an effect on other groups within this document as individual rule require certain controls to be selected.

Profile.title: 800-53 All
Profile.description: This profile selects all the security controls that are recommended by Special Publication 800-53 for information systems. Each control has an effect on other groups within this document as individual rule require certain controls to be selected.

Profile.title: Federal Desktop Core Configuration version 1.2.1.0
Profile.description: This profile represents guidance outlined in Federal Core Configuration settings for Windows Vista Firewall on desktop systems.

Group.title: Account Management
Group.reference: GAO FISCAM: AC-2.1 AC-2.2, AC-3.2, SP-4.1

Group.title: Access Enforcement
Group.reference: DOD 8500.2: DCFA-1, ECAN-1, EBRU-1, PRNK-1, ECCD-1, ECSD-2
DCID 6/3: Discretionary Access Control (DAC): 4.B.2.a(2), Mandatory Access Control (MAC): 4.B.4.a(3)

Group.title: Permitted Actions without Identification or Authentication
Access Control for Portable and Mobile Systems
Security Awareness and Training Policy and Procedures
Contacts with Security Groups and Associations
Audit and Accountability Policy and Procedures
Applicable 800-53 Certification, Accreditation, and Security Assessment
Certification, Accreditation, and Security Assessment Policies and Procedures
Information System Connections
Group.reference: DOD 8500.2: DCID-1, EBCR-1 EBRU-1, EBPW-1, ECIC-1

Group.title: Baseline Configuration and System Component Inventory
Identification and Authentication Policy and Procedures
Physical and Environmental Protection Policy and Procedures
System and Services Acquisition Policy and Procedures
Information System Documentation
Group.reference: DOD 8500.2: DCCS-1, DCHW-1, DCID-1, DCSD-1, DCSW-1, ECND-1, DCFA-1

Group.title: System and Communications Protection Policy and Procedures
Secure Name Address Resolution Service (Authoritative Source)
Architecture and Provisioning for Name/Address Resolution Service
System and Information Integrity Policy and Procedures
Information System Monitoring Tools and Techniques
Information Accuracy, Completeness, Validity, and Authenticity
Introduction
Group.description:
This guide has been created to assist federal agencies in effectively securing systems with Microsoft Windows Vista Firewall based on OMB Federal Desktop Core Configuration recommendations.
Under the direction of OMB and in collaboration with DHS, DISA, NSA, USAF, and Microsoft, NIST has provided the following baseline to help agencies test, implement, and deploy the Microsoft Windows Vista Firewall Federal Desktop Core Configuration (FDCC) baseline. The Federal Desktop Core Configuration (FDCC) is an OMB-mandated security configuration.
Please refer to the FDCC home page for additional information. http://fdcc.nist.gov

Group.title: FDCC Other Settings
Group.description: FDCC has identified the following additional controls that must be checked in order to verify compliance.

Rule.title: IPv6 Block of Protocols 41
Rule.description: todo - description needed

reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Outbound Rules

Rule.title: IPv6 Block of UDP 3544
Rule.description: todo - description needed

reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Outbound Rules

Group.title: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security - Domain Profile
Group.description: The Domain Profile applies when a computer is connected to a network and authenticates to a domain controller in the domain to which the computer belongs.

Value.title: domain_profile_log_dropped_packets_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: domain_profile_logged_successful_connections_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: domain_profile_name_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: domain_profile_size_limit_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: Display a Notification
Value.description: The Domain Profile is used when the computer is connected to a network and is authenticated to a domain controller.

Value.title: Apply Local Connection Security Rules
Value.description: The Domain Profile is used when the computer is connected to a network and is authenticated to a domain controller.

Value.title: Apply Local Firewall Rules
Value.description: The Domain Profile is used when the computer is connected to a network and is authenticated to a domain controller.

Value.description: The Domain Profile is used when the computer is connected to a network and is authenticated to a domain controller.

Value.description: The Domain Profile is used when the computer is connected to a network and is authenticated to a domain controller.

Rule.title: Log Dropped Packets
Rule.description: The "Log Dropped Packets" option for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile Tab\Logging

Rule.title: Logged Successful Connections
Rule.description: The "Log Successful Connections" option for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

Rule.title: Name
Rule.description: The log file path and name for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

Rule.title: Size Limit
Rule.description: The log file size limit for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

Group.title: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security - Private Profile
Group.description: The Public Profile is the default network location type when the computer is not connected to a domain. Public profile settings should be the most restrictive because the computer is connected to a public network where security cannot be as tightly controlled as within an IT environment.

Value.title: private_profile_log_dropped_packets_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: private_profile_logged_successful_connections_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: private_profile_name_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: private_profile_size_limit_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: Display a Notification
Value.description: The Private Profile is used only if a local administrator changes the profile for a computer connected previously to a public network (using a Public Profile).

Value.title: Apply Local Connection Security Rules
Value.description: The Private Profile is used only if a local administrator changes the profile for a computer connected previously to a public network (using a Public Profile).

Group.title: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security - Public Profile
Group.description: The Private Profile only applies if a user with local administrator privileges assigns it to a network that was previously set to Public. Microsoft recommends only doing this for a trusted network.

Value.title: public_profile_log_dropped_packets_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: public_profile_logged_successful_connections_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: public_profile_name_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: public_profile_size_limit_var
Value.description: todo

Value.title: Display a Notification
Value.description: The Public Profile is the default profile for a computer connected to a public network but not connected to a domain controller. This should be the most restricted profile.

Value.description: The Public Profile is the default profile for a computer connected to a public network but not connected to a domain controller. This should be the most restricted profile.
